photo.description: The Terracotta Army - bronze chariots, Xi'an China. This is 'Chariot number 1' : a two-wheeled vehicle drawn by a team of four horses. Two large scale-models of bronze chariots and horses were unearthed in 1980, about 20m (65.6 ft) east of the mausoleum of Emperor Qin Shi Huang. These were encased in a wooden box measuring 6.8x2.1x2m (22.3x6.8x6.5 ft) for over two thousand years. The box was buried at a depth of 8m (26.2 ft). (Tour by Xi'an Self Tour)

photo.title: Terracotta Army

photo.description: Terracotta Army, Xi'An, Shaanxi province, China The Terracotta Army is a collection of terracotta sculptures depicting the armies of Qin Shi Huang, the first Emperor of China. It is a form of funerary art buried with the emperor in 210–209 BC and whose purpose was to protect the emperor in his afterlife. Current estimates are that in the three pits containing the Terracotta Army there were over 8,000 soldiers, 130 chariots with 520 horses and 150 cavalry horses, the majority of which are still buried. The Terracotta Army was discovered on 29 March 1974 to the east of Xi'an in Shaanxi province by a group of farmers when they were digging a water well. This is one of seven generals so far found in the excavations. He was leaning on a sword, which has a chrome plated surface. This acted as a coating protecting against corrosion. The sword is still sharp enough to cut through a stack of paper. The chrome plating technology was re-invented by the germans in 1937 and the americans in 1950. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terracotta_Army

photo.description: View of Pit 1 at the Terracotta Museum in Xi'an. Notice the ruined figures in the right corner of the photograph. This is probably the result of a Han-soldier's actions, venting his anger with the Qin Dynasty on a terracotta figure, some 2220 years ago.

photo.description: Reassembled terracotta warriors lined up in Pit 1 of the Terracotta Museum. It's almost like looking at live soldiers, a bit dirty perhaps and dressed in old costumes. Very impressive!
photo.tags: kinatur dse deepskyexploration china kina shaanxi xian sian terracottaarmy terracottamuseum qinshihuangterracottawarriorsandhorsesmuseum
photo.title: Terracotta Warriors

photo.description: The terracotta warriors are all individually modelled, probably after real persons and / or warriors. The army was buried to protect the emperor Qin in his afterlife, so they are part of his vast mausoleum outside Xi'an. Qin Shi Huang or Emperor Qin was the first to rule a united China, but his Qin Dynasty only lasted from 221 to 210 BCE - when he died. After his death a new dynasty took over the control of China, the famous Han Dynasty, that would last for more than four hundred years and forever set its mark on Chinese culture and language.
photo.tags: kinatur dse deepskyexploration china kina shaanxi xian sian terracottaarmy terracottamuseum qinshihuangterracottawarriorsandhorsesmuseum
photo.title: The Terracotta Army in Xi'an

photo.description: The impressive Terracotta army was first unearthed in 1974, after more than 2200 years in the ground, after some local farmers had discovered fragments of terracotta figures while digging a well. This photo was taken at Pit 1, the oldest of three archeological pits at the museum. In Pit 1 there are 38 columns of Terracotta Warriors, with around 6000 warriors in total! All three pits are still being excavated and the current estimate is that they contain some 8000 warriors, 130 chariots with 520 horses and 150 cavalry horses, the majority of which are still buried in the pits. Some 10 thousand bronze weapons have also been unearthed. The museum and Pit 1 was opened to the public in 1979, in 1987 UNESCO named it a World Heritage Site and today it is often referred to as the "8th Wonder of the World".

photo.description: The Terracotta Army (Pit 1), Xi'an China. Pit one, first opened to the public in 1979, is 230m (754.6 ft) long, it contains the main Terracotta army, estimated at 8,000 figures of which 1,000 have been unearthed. Pit One has 11 corridors, most of which are over 3m (9.8 ft) wide. (Tour by Xi'an Self Tour)

photo.description: The Terracotta Army (Pit 3), Xi'an China. Pit 3 measures 17.5m (57.6 ft) long from east to west, 21.4m (70.2 ft) wide from north to south and is 4.8m (15.7 ft) deep. Pit 3 is appears to be the command centre or headquarters for all the groups in the other two pits. So far 68 terracotta warriors, four horses and one chariot have been unearthed. (Tour by Xi'an Self Tour)

photo.title: The Terracotta Army, Xi'an

photo.description: The Terracotta Army (Pit 1), Xi'an China. The Terracotta Army was discovered in 1974 in the eastern suburbs of Xi'an, by local farmers drilling a water well 2.4km (1.5 miles) east of Lishan (a mountain). This (picture) is pit one, the largest of the four; the sight that was to once to be a water well is out of view to the left of this photo. The Terracotta Army is a form of funerary art buried with the First Emperor of Qin (Qin Shi Huang (秦始皇) (259 BCE – 210 BCE), was king of the Chinese State of Qin from 246 BCE to 221 BCE. He became the first emperor of a unified China in 221 BCE) in 210 BCE. Their purpose was to help rule another empire with Shi Huang Di in the afterlife. (Tour by Xi'an Self Tour)

photo.title: General

photo.description: The Terracotta Army or the "Terra Cotta Warriors and Horses", is a collection of terracotta sculptures depicting the armies of Qin Shi Huang, the first Emperor of China. It is a form of funerary art buried with the emperor in 210–209 BC and whose purpose was to protect the emperor in his afterlife. The figures, dating from 3rd century BC, were discovered in 1974 by some local farmers in Lintong District, Xi'an, Shaanxi province, near the Mausoleum of the First Qin Emperor. The figures vary in height according to their roles, with the tallest being the generals. The figures include warriors, chariots and horses. Current estimates are that in the three pits containing the Terracotta Army there were over 8,000 soldiers, 130 chariots with 520 horses and 150 cavalry horses, the majority of which are still buried in the pits. Other terracotta non-military figures were also found in other pits and they include officials, acrobats, strongmen and musicians. (From Wikipedia, en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terracotta_Army)
photo.tags: xian terracottaarmy china terracotta army shaanxi
photo.title: Xi'an, Terracotta Army

photo.description: These restored Terracotta Warriors are part of the Terracotta Army ordered by Qin Shi Huang, the first Emperor of all China, around 200BC. He believed that his army would go with him to the afterlife so he could continue to rule there. Tens of thousands of life-size figures, including horses, have been discovered at the site with far more yet to be unearthed. Originally they were all painted in bright colours, not the familiar terracotta look we see today.
photo.tags: china xian terracottaarmy terracottawarriors
photo.title: Attention!

photo.description: The Terracotta Army - bronze chariots, Xi'an China. Two large scale-models of bronze chariots and horses were unearthed in 1980, about 20m (65.6 ft) east of the mausoleum of Emperor Qin Shi Huang. These were encased in a wooden box measuring 6.8x2.1x2m (22.3x6.8x6.5 ft) for over two thousand years. The box was buried at a depth of 8m (26.2 ft). (Tour by Xi'an Self Tour)

photo.description: The Terracotta Army - bronze chariots, Xi'an China. This is 'Chariot number 2' : a two-wheeled enclosed carriage drawn by a team of four horses. Two large scale-models of bronze chariots and horses were unearthed in 1980, about 20m (65.6 ft) east of the mausoleum of Emperor Qin Shi Huang. These were encased in a wooden box measuring 6.8x2.1x2m (22.3x6.8x6.5 ft) for over two thousand years. The box was buried at a depth of 8m (26.2 ft). (Tour by Xi'an Self Tour)

photo.title: The Terracotta Army - bronze chariots, Xi'an

photo.description: Notice their hands are in positioned as if they were holding weapons. The wooden spears and other weapons they were burried with have since rotted away. 40,000 metal parts, including spear and axe heads, have been found.
photo.tags: china xian terracottaarmy terracottawarriors
photo.title: Terracotta Warriors

photo.description: This pit in Vault 2 has not been fully restored. Vault 2 is though to contain more warriors than Vault 1's estimated 8,000.
photo.tags: china xian terracottaarmy terracottawarriors
photo.title: Pit of despair

photo.description: The Terracotta Army (Pit 3), Xi'an China.
photo.tags: china 中国 peoplesrepublicofchina 中华人民共和国 prc xīān sian 西安 xian lintong líntóng 临潼 qinshihuang 秦始皇 qínshǐhuáng terracottaarmy 兵马俑 bīngmǎyǒng soldierandhorsefunerarystatues terracottawarriorsandhorses terracottawarriors terracottawarrior terracottasoldiers terracottasoldier pitthree pit3 uphigh fromabove viewfromthetop above viewfromabove
photo.title: The Terracotta Army, Xi'an

photo.description: The Terracotta Army (Pit 1), Xi'an China. Archaeologists at work on the third excavation of Pit 1. Pit 1 has been excavated twice. The first excavation occurred between 1978 and 1984 when 1,787 pieces of terracotta warriors were unearthed. The second excavation was in 1985 but was stopped in the same year because the equipment and technology at that time could not protect the relics. Those two previous excavations only covered one third of the total area in Pit 1. (Tour by Xi'an Self Tour)

photo.description: The Terracotta Army of Qin Shi Huang. No two of the figures look identical; they vary in costumes, size and hairstyle according to the rank. Even though all figures were constructed with a fixed set of moulds, the artisans later worked on it to give individual features.

photo.title: Broken statues

photo.description: View from the side of Pit 1 at the Terracotta Museum in Xi'an. Visitors to the pit can walk around the excavated area, looking down at the terracotta army. It's a very popular tourist attraction so you often have to fight for your space at the railing, in order to get a photograph without arms and heads obscuring the view.
photo.tags: kinatur dse deepskyexploration china kina shaanxi xian sian terracottaarmy terracottamuseum qinshihuangterracottawarriorsandhorsesmuseum
photo.title: The Terracotta army

photo.description: Terracotta Warriors in Pit 1 of the Terracotta Museum in Xi'an.
photo.tags: kinatur dse deepskyexploration china kina shaanxi xian sian terracottaarmy terracottamuseum qinshihuangterracottawarriorsandhorsesmuseum
photo.title: Terracotta Warriors

photo.description: Information board at the entrance to Pit 3 of the Terracotta Museum in Xi'an. Pit 3 is the newest and smallest of the three pits, just one tenth the size of Pit 2, and was discovered in June 1976. It's more ruined than the two other pits, possibly because it was here that figures of the commanding officers were located (they were more feared and hated by the Han-soldiers that destroyed the Qin mausoleum). Only 68 terracotta figures, one chariot and 34 bronze weapons have been unearthed from this pit.
photo.tags: kinatur dse deepskyexploration china kina shaanxi xian sian terracottaarmy terracottamuseum qinshihuangterracottawarriorsandhorsesmuseum
photo.title: Pit 3 @ Terracotta Museum

photo.description: Standing at the very back of the huge vault over Pit 1 at the Terrracotta Museum in Xi'an. The light in the distance is from the windows above the entrance. The pit is 230 m long, 62 m wide and 5 m deep.
photo.tags: kinatur dse deepskyexploration china kina shaanxi xian sian terracottaarmy terracottamuseum qinshihuangterracottawarriorsandhorsesmuseum
photo.title: Pit 1 @ Terracotta Museum

photo.description: Information board at the entrance of the Terracotta Museum, formally known as Qin Shi Huang Terracotta Warriors and Horses Museum, some 20 km north-west of the city of Xi'an. The map shows the location of the three pits, where the terracotta army is still being excavated.
photo.tags: kinatur dse deepskyexploration china kina shaanxi xian sian terracottaarmy terracottamuseum qinshihuangterracottawarriorsandhorsesmuseum
photo.title: The Terracotta Museum

photo.description: On the lawn in front of the entrance to Pit 1 of the Qin Shi Huang Terracotta Warriors and Horses Museum.
photo.tags: kinatur dse deepskyexploration china kina shaanxi xian sian terracottaarmy terracottamuseum qinshihuangterracottawarriorsandhorsesmuseum
photo.title: Pit 1 at the Terracotta Museum

photo.description: View of a less excavated part of Pit 1 at the Terracotta Museum in Xi'an. The half-buried terracotta figures are clearly ruined, many missing the head, and it will take both time and effort to restore this part of the pit to its former glory.
photo.tags: kinatur dse deepskyexploration china kina shaanxi xian sian terracottaarmy terracottamuseum qinshihuangterracottawarriorsandhorsesmuseum
photo.title: Pit 1 @ Terracotta Museum

photo.description: Even though Pit 1 at the Terracotta Museum has been excavated for 35 years, since 1974, much work still remains to uncover all the artifacts and to reassemble broken figures. Much of the destruction to the warrior figures were actually done shortly after the death of emperor Qin, when the Han-uprising took place. When the Han troops conquered Xi'an they burned down and destroyed much of the capital and the monuments left after the Qin Dynasty. Including the mausoleum with the Terracotta Army. Thus, many of the broken terracotta warriors have been broken almost since the day they were buried with their emperor!
photo.tags: kinatur dse deepskyexploration china kina shaanxi xian sian terracottaarmy terracottamuseum qinshihuangterracottawarriorsandhorsesmuseum
photo.title: The Terracotta army

photo.description: Close-up view of Terracotta Warriors in Pit 1 at the Terracotta Museum. Some of the soldiers haven't been completely reassembled but have gaping holes in their sides, where fragments are missing (possibly still awaiting excavation).
photo.tags: kinatur dse deepskyexploration china kina shaanxi xian sian terracottaarmy terracottamuseum qinshihuangterracottawarriorsandhorsesmuseum
photo.title: Terracotta Warriors

photo.description: Visitors at Pit 1, viewing the impressive Terracotta Army of emperor Qin.
photo.tags: kinatur dse deepskyexploration china kina shaanxi xian sian terracottaarmy terracottamuseum qinshihuangterracottawarriorsandhorsesmuseum
photo.title: Visitors to the Terracotta army

photo.description: Terracotta Warriors in Pit 3 of the Terracotta Museum in Xi'an.
photo.tags: kinatur dse deepskyexploration china kina shaanxi xian sian terracottaarmy terracottamuseum qinshihuangterracottawarriorsandhorsesmuseum
photo.title: Pit 3 @ Terracotta Museum

photo.description: A terracotta figure of a leading archer by Pit 2 at the Terracotta Museum in Xi'an. The Chinese are rightly proud of their terracotty army, notice the gaping school children looking up in awe at this 2200 years old warrior statue.
photo.tags: kinatur dse deepskyexploration china kina shaanxi xian sian terracottaarmy terracottamuseum qinshihuangterracottawarriorsandhorsesmuseum terracottawarrior leadingarcher
photo.title: Leading archer

photo.description: The Terracotta Museum is located some 20 km northwest of Xi'an, with rolling mountains to its north and a nice green park covering the museum area. Despite the crowds, this museum is a must on a trip to China!
photo.tags: kinatur dse deepskyexploration china kina shaanxi xian sian terracottaarmy terracottamuseum qinshihuangterracottawarriorsandhorsesmuseum
photo.title: Terracotta Museum

photo.description: This terracotta figure is of a leading archer, which can be seen from the kneeling position they used in battle (they were at the very front of the battle and so had to kneel in order for the second line of archers to shoot their arrows without hitting archers in the first line!). This figure was on display next to Pit 2, at the Terracotta Museum in Xi'an.
photo.tags: kinatur dse deepskyexploration china kina shaanxi xian sian terracottaarmy terracottamuseum qinshihuangterracottawarriorsandhorsesmuseum leadingarcher terracottawarrior
photo.title: Leading archer

photo.description: Arriving at the smallest and less excavated Pit 3, after visiting Pit 1, may come as a bit of a letdown. Still, it is interesting to see the "headless wonders" of the terracotta army; this photo clearly illustrates how a warrior was made, the body was mass produced and then the head, with its individual features, was stuck into the hole in the neck. Presumably, some of these terracotta warriors lost their heads to the raging Han-mob some 2220 years ago.
photo.tags: kinatur dse deepskyexploration china kina shaanxi xian sian terracottaarmy terracottamuseum qinshihuangterracottawarriorsandhorsesmuseum
photo.title: Pit 3 @ Terracotta Museum

photo.description: View of pit 2 at the Terracotta Museum in Xi'an. This pit is a little less than half the size of Pit 1 and is expected to contain around 500 terracotta warriors (compared to 6000 in Pit 1). As this photo clearly illustrates, much excavation work remains to unearth the terracotta figures in Pit 2!
photo.tags: kinatur dse deepskyexploration china kina shaanxi xian sian terracottaarmy terracottamuseum qinshihuangterracottawarriorsandhorsesmuseum
photo.title: Pit 2 @ Terracotta Museum
